text:
So it's now my pleasure
to introduce the 2023

Alumni Achievement
Award recipients.

Throughout their careers,
these distinguished graduates

have contributed significantly
to their companies

and communities, while
upholding the highest standards

and values in
everything they do.

As such, they represent the
best in our alumni body,
exemplary role models.

They inspire all
those who aspire

to have an impact on both
business and society.
Reshma, if you may come.
Please stand and come here.
I'll read out your citation.

Reshma Kewalramani at 11
years old was excited.

She and her family
were flying from India

to a land where the streets
were paved with gold.

When she arrived on
Long Island, the reality
was a bit different.

The other sixth graders
didn't understand

her English or why
she wasn't allowed
to spend Saturday at the mall.

Instead, Reshma bonded
with her teachers,

discovering the magic
of math and science.

That manic magic connected with
her love of helping others.

Reshma became a
doctor and then found

what she really wanted to do was
make life changing medicines.

Recruited by Amgen,
she rose to lead its US
medical organization.

Then in 2017, this
Bostonian by way of Bombay

came to Vertex
Pharmaceuticals working

on a drug that would transform
the lives of cystic fibrosis
patients.

In April, 2020,
Reshma made history

as the first female
CEO and president
of a major biotech firm.

Today, she leads a
global team working

on treatments for a range of
diseases that affect millions.

Never forgetting how
encouragement shaped her life,

Reshma gives her
time to organizations

that support
underrepresented groups
in pursuing STEM careers.

Her remarkable
trajectory reminds

us of what is possible when
we take risks and follow
our hearts.
Reshma, if you please--

so please join me in
congratulating Reshma
Kemalramani on the [INAUDIBLE].
[APPLAUSE, CHEERS]
Depelsha Thomas McGruder.
Depelsha, please come.

Born in Rome, Georgia
Depelsha Thomas McGruder

grew up an introvert content to
spend time with her thoughts.

Years later, she found a
voice as a journalist and news

anchor, and realized
she wanted to shape
the conversation at its source.

After earning her MBA, Depelsha
fulfilled that aspiration

by joining Viacom where she
spent nearly 17 years launching

networks to serve new
communities of viewers.

Then in July 2016,
on consecutive days,

Alton Sterling and Philando
Castile were shot by police.

It was a painfully
familiar scenario.

But this time, Depelsha
was moved to action.

She started a private
Facebook group,
Moms of Black Boys United.

12 hours later, it
had 21,000 members.

Today, as a result
of her leadership,

it is a nationwide nonprofit,
advocating and legislating

for the equitable treatment
of Black boys and men.

In June 2020,
Depelsha was recruited

to the Ford Foundation as
treasurer and chief operating
officer.

She leverages a $16 billion
endowment for impact
on a global scale.

Her quiet drive
and determination

demonstrate how one
person can truly
make a difference in the world.

Please join me in congratulating
Depelsha Thomas McGruder.

Want to next recognize
Raymond J. Maguire.
[APPLAUSE, CHEERS]

Ray McGuire grew
up in Dayton, Ohio

raised by a single mother who
stood strong in the belief

that her son would
achieve great things.

Ray started on that path
by excelling academically

and serving as school president
and captain of the basketball
team.

Then in 11th grade,
a teacher challenged
him to test himself out East.

He flew to
Connecticut by himself

and took a Greyhound
bus around New England,

spending his senior
year at Hotchkiss.

At HBS, a classmate suggested
Ray try this investment banking
stuff.

He did, winning the coveted
spot at First Boston.

From there, he went on
to Wasserstein Perella

and Company, Merrill
Lynch, and Morgan Stanley

before joining
Citigroup in 2005 where

he rose to vice chair and
chair of its banking, capital
markets, and advisory business.

Today, as president of Lazard,
Ray's journey continues.

A long-time resident
of New York City,

he serves on the boards
of landmark institutions

from the Studio Museum in Harlem
to the New York Public Library

to New York
Presbyterian Hospital.

While Ray's mother
is no longer with us,

she lived long enough to see
her prayers answered in full.

A success on every
level, Ray McGuire

continues to move
forward fearlessly,

never forgetting
where he came from

or the importance of
passing the torch to others.

Please join me in
congratulating Ray McGuire.
[APPLAUSE, CHEERS]
[INAUDIBLE]
Antonis Samaras.
Please come.

The son of a cardiologist,
Antonis Samaras

was expected to follow in
his father's footsteps.

But one day, a
friend pulled him out

of chemistry lab
at Amherst College

to hear a talk by John
Kenneth Galbraith.

Fascinated, Antonis changed
his major to economics.

After HBS, when he
went home to Greece,
Antonis led the new democracy--

New Democracy Party's
youth Organization,

then was asked by Greece's prime
minister to run for parliament.

Elected at age 26, he is
now serving his 14th term
in the District of Messenia.

Few careers are as punishing
and unpredictable as politics.

Yet, Antonis has kept
the focus on what

drives him, a love of people
and a love of problem solving.

Elected prime minister in
2012, he led his country

through the Greek debt crisis,
implementing tax increasing--

increases, and spending
cuts, and undergoing

intense negotiations to
stay in the eurozone.

This tough stance did not
win Antonis re-election,

but he doesn't
regret straying to--

staying true to his beliefs,
a principle that has also

guided him as
minister of finance,

minister of foreign affairs,
and minister of culture.

It is the care and
respect Antonis embodies

in serving the Greek people
that will shape his legacy,

shining a bright light for
future generations of leaders.

Please join me in
congratulating Antonis Samaras.
[APPLAUSE, CHEERS]
[INAUDIBLE]
Stephen A. Schwarzman, MBA 1972.

When he was a teenager,
Stephen Schwarzman

learned the power of
two words, go big.

As high school
president, he didn't
settle for hiring a local band.

Instead, he recruited Little
Anthony and the Imperials.

It was a school dance
unlike any other.

And one of many times, Steve
would upend the status quo
with dramatic results.

In 1985, when he
co-founded Blackstone,

Steve had already made
headlines at Lehman

as a merger maker
with the rare ability

to really listen to and
understand people's needs.

But a deafening silence
greeted Blackstone's launch.

When the phone did
finally begin to ring,

Steve answered it with
the success of one deal

feeding the next, and
the next, and the next.

Today, Blackstone is the world's
largest alternative asset

manager with investments
in private equity,

real estate, public
debt and equity,
insurance, and infrastructure.

Steve attributes
Blackstone's success

to its culture, built
on the power of inquiry,
meritocracy, and openness.

A similar spirit
drives his philanthropy

with foundational gifts to Yale,
Oxford, and MIT to name a few.

Endlessly curious
and creative, Steve
shows no signs of slowing down.

Clearly, go big remains
his catchphrase.

And it has yielded
immeasurable impact.

Please join me in
congratulating Steve Schwarzman.
[APPLAUSE, CHEERS]

They're going to
take some photos.
What an inspirational group.

To all of us, and I think
especially to our graduates,

if I could just take the
liberty of asking for one more

round of applause for all of
our Alumni Achievement Award
winners.
[APPLAUSE, CHEERS]
